titleStmt.title: John Quincy Adams Diary Digital Project

div.p: 1. I employed almost the whole of this day in arranging my own affairs, and bringing up arrears of account-books; Journal &c— Found an error in Mr: Storer’s calculation, and wrote to him concerning it— My father was here in the forenoon, and I went down to his house in the Evening— On my return I read another Section of the Tale of the Tub. George returned home from my father’s this Evening.

2. Heard Mr: Guild, a young Candidate who is preaching at Milton— Dined with all my family at my father’s—and I went there again in the afternoon— I came home early with George. Read a couple of Barrow’s Lectures— Mr: T. Greenleaf junr: was here part of the Evening—

3. A Town-meeting was held this day for the Election of members to the tenth Congress; but I did not attend it— Mr: T. Greenleaf and Mr: D. Greenleaf, with their families, and Mrs: Blake spent the Evening with us. I employed the day as industriously as I was able; but neither read nor wrote much.

4. Employed all the forenoon in writing for the Trustees of J. Boylston’s donation— In the afternoon took a ride with my wife and children to Squantum— In the Evening read two Acts of Shakespear’s Henry 4. Part 1.

5. I have almost abandoned my regular course of study; compelled by necessary attention to other objects previous to my departure for the Winter— I was engaged this day chiefly in writing to Mr: N. Webster— In answer to a letter which I received from him some time since— Spent part of the Evening at my father’s.

6. I went into Boston this morning; and employed the day there in seeking lodgings for my family during the Winter. I found at length Apartments in Poplar Street, at a Mr: Gulliver’s— I saw him, and agreed to send him a final answer before the end of the week— Looked over also Mr: Boylston’s papers, respecting his controversy with Willis—which I am to take on with me to Baltimore— Saw Mr: T. Perkins, and gave him my written opinion respecting their dispute with Mr: Boylston— Dined at Dr: Welsh’s—and in the Evening returned to Quincy with Caroline Johnson— We lost from the Chaise a Basket, containing her clothes.— We return’d several miles back to recover it, but without success.— We reached home, about 9 in the Evening.

7. My brother called this morning, and invited me to go on a shooting party with him, for Partridges and Woodcocks— I went with him but we met with no success— I dined, and spent the afternoon at my father’s— Return’d home early in the Evening— I looked over the first volume of Condillac’s Cours d’Etude— His plan of Instruction seems to me too metaphysical— He deals too much in abstractions for a child of seven year’s old— He lays it down as a fundamental axiom that Children at that age are capable of Reasoning, and his system is built upon that principle.— His preliminary lessons seem to me to require a Child of 14 at least. Mrs: Smith and T. Greenleaf junr: were with the Ladies when I came home.
8. My mother was here this afternoon at tea, with Louisa Smith— In the Evening I went down to my father’s— I employed the day upon business of various kinds— But neither wrote nor read much.
9. Heard Mr: Porter the whole day— In the afternoon I went down to my father’s, and returned early in the Evening with George— Read the Odyssey Books 21. and 22. and the 3d: Act of Henry 4. part 1.

10. My brother dined with us— In the afternoon I went with Mrs: Adams to Mrs: Mitchell’s; and afterwards I went to my father’s— Mr: Shaw came out there from Boston, while I was there— After returning I read the Odyssey. Book 23.

11. My father and brother, with their families dined with us.— In the Evening, Mr: T. Greenleaf junr: was here. Afterwards I read the 24th: & last Book of Pope’s Odyssey.— Finished reading the Greek Testament.

12. I went to Cambridge, and attended the meeting of the Academy.— My father intended to have gone; but found himself so unwell that he concluded not to go out. Mrs: Cranch went with me, and took her little Grandson John Greenleaf with her— The Academy meeting was better attended than I expected, and there were several communications received— I dined at Mr: Ware’s; with several others of the members. It was 3 O’Clock before the meeting ended. And past four before I could get away— We returned through Boston, where it was my intention to have stop’d, for the Night; but it grew very dark, and Mrs: Cranch appearing uneasy; the driver being young & not very expert, that I determined to come home with her— Between 7 and 8 in the Evening we got safely home— Our Company at Mr: Ware’s, was Mr: Freeman, Dr: Kirkland, Mr: Gannett and Dr: Waterhouse; the last of whom had not attended the meeting of the Academy.— Began reading the Odyssey in Greek.

13. I went into Boston this morning with Mrs: Adams in the Stage—and we returned at Night— We called at the lodgings I had engaged for Mrs: Adams in Poplar Street— I saw Mr: Storer—Mr: Boylston, and Mr: Foster; and made some arrangements previous to my departure for Washington— Evening at home— I was much fatigued, and gave the Evening to relaxation.

14. We employed the greatest part of the day in packing up, and prepared two loads of furniture to go off to-morrow morning, for Boston— In the Evening I went to my father’s; where I looked up some papers respecting my farm—which I propose to lease in several parcels for the year ensuing— There was company at my father’s at tea. I returned home later than usual— We have sent our children,—George to Mr: Cranch’s, and John to my father’s to remain untill we go in to Boston—

15. We sent our furniture into Boston this morning— I went with Mr: Briesler and viewed the metes and bounds over the greatest part of my farm— About noon A storm of rain came on which continued through the whole remainder of the day— Mr: Vesey was here all the Evening, bargaining to hire part of my farm; but we could not agree upon terms.

16. After raining the whole Night, the weather this morning changed to Snow, which continued, the whole day through— I waited untill the Evening, and then walked down to my father’s; after stopping at Mr: Cranch’s, to see George— I spent the Evening in advising with my brother respecting my Affairs which I leave under his care— Pass’d the Night at my father’s.

17. Early this morning I went up to my own house, and at 8. O’Clock with Mrs: Adams, and Caroline and Sally Cleverly we proceeded in the Stage to Boston— Stopp’d at Mr: Cranch’s, and took George in with us; but John we left for two or three days at my father’s— Untill the ladies get fixed and settled at their lodgings.— On arriving in Boston, we were occupied the whole day in arranging and ordering the apartments where the family are to remain— I dined at Whitcomb’s with a numerous company, chiefly consisting of English Officers—

18. Employed the day altogether in making arrangements for my family; and preparations for my own departure to-morrow morning. Dined with Mr: D. Sears; Mr: F. Geyer junr: was there— I received from Mr: Osgood a plan for building upon the land where my house in Court-Street stands—which I propose to do next Spring, or as soon after as I can accomplish— Evening at home—

19. At 8 this morning, I left my wife and family at their lodgings at Mr: B. Gulliver’s in Poplar-Street, and took the Stage by the middle road to Hartford— I had at first only one travelling companion; a young woman who came only as far as Mendon. at Dedham, we took in a Lady to Medfield; and a Mr: Whiting, who was going as far as Hartford— At Mendon, where we dined Mr: Hastings joined us—the member of Congress from the South District of Worcester County— He was also going on to Washington. About 8 in the Evening we arrived at Holbrook’s tavern in Thompson, the first Connecticut town; and there we put up for the Night— The distance from Boston is 54 Miles— That to Mendon is 35.

20. We left Thompson this morning at about 7. and rode to Coventry 31. miles to dinner. Then 16 miles to Hartford; where after crossing Connecticut River, we arrived just after 5 in the afternoon— This road is about 20 miles nearer than that by the way of Springfield, and the roads are better— At Hartford we found Mr: Taggart, the Representative from the South District of Hampshire County, who is to proceed in Company with us— Here Mr: Whiting parted from us.

21. Our Stage did not leave Hartford untill 10 this Morning— We travell’d through Weathersfield, and Middletown— At which last place we took in Mr: Dana, the member from Connecticut— We dined at Derham, twenty one miles from Hartford; and thence rode twenty miles further to New-Haven— This place we reached between 5 and 6 in the Evening— Mr: Dana by way of amusement to himself and his fellow-travellers, stopp’d us at the house of one Elliot, a democratic geographer, who considers himself as profoundly versed in the whole map of Europe— He had lately been to New-Haven, and there purchased the volume of my letters upon Silesia, which he had read with much care, and pleased himself with detailing to me its principal contents— At New-Haven we
we stopp’d only to sup at Butler’s, and at 8 in the Evening, embarked on board the Packet Augusta, Captain Beecher, for New-York— We sailed at about 9. with fine weather, and a bright moon; but almost a total calm— Besides Mr: Hastings, Mr: Taggart and Mr: Dana, we were now joined by Mr: Dwight, with his Lady; and Mr: Pitken; and also by Mr: Thompson, of New-Hampshire—

22. There was so little wind through the last Night, and this day, that we were not able to accomplish a voyage, which is often performed in seven or eight hours— The tediousness of this lingering time is in some sort aggravated by the want of books; but is much alleviated by the pleasant humour of our companions; particularly Mr: Dana and Mr: Pitken— The only reading I could find, was Mr: Bidwell’s Tragedy, called the Mercenary Match; which was lent me by Mr: Dwight— It was written and printed while Bidwell was at College, and now affords great entertainment to his enemies.

23. We anchored below Hell-Gate; at about 4. O’Clock this morning; for two or three hours untill the turn of the tide. About 10 O’Clock in the forenoon we landed at the wharf in New-York; and I went to the City-Hotel— The Packet which sailed from New-Haven the Night before us, arrived about a quarter of an hour after us; and that which sailed last Evening arrived within three hours later—a singular indication of the progress of an easterly breeze after a calm, in the Sound.— I engaged my passage in the Diligence Stage, to Philadelphia—to go to-morrow morning, and spent this day at Coll: Smith’s— His brother Justus was there; and Mr: Ogden, dined with us— The situation of the Coll’s: family is distressing, and their prospects are gloomy— I saw there Mr: & Mrs: Shaw; and Mrs:in the Evening I called and pass’d an hour at Mr: M’Cormick’s.

24. This morning at 8 we cross’d the ferry at Paulus Hoek, and took the Diligence for Philadelphia. Some of the Gentlemen, with whom I had come to New-York parted from us there, and others have taken their places— Our present company consists of Mr: Hastings, Mr: Thompson, Mr: Ely, and Mr: Hough—with a Gentleman belonging to Hartford; not a member of Congress— We dined at Woodbridge, and came this Evening to Princeton—54 miles— Arrived at about 8 in the Evening— I called immediately on the President of the College, Dr: Smith; to thank him and his Lady for the kindness they had shewn to my wife, and Caroline Johnson, when they were here in the Summer— I also thanked him for the personal notice they have taken of me at their last annual Commencement at this College.

25. About 6 this morning we left Princeton— Breakfasted at Trenton, where I met Mr: Cadwalader, and at 1/2 past two, reached the City Hotel in Philadelphia— After dinner I called at Mr: Meredith’s—Dr: Rush’s, Mr Hopkinson’s; but without finding any of them at home— At Mrs: Roberts’s, I found Dr: Fothergill, to whom I mentioned the reading of his paper at the meeting of the American Academy— Dr: Chapman was not at home— In the Evening I went to hear Fennell’s Readings & Recitations, which appeared to me, to be very indifferent— I met there Mr: Gaillard of S. Carolina—and Mr: Sailly and Dr: Russell; members from New-York— I had also seen them all there.

26. The hour fixed for the sailing of the New Castle Packet, was 7. this morning; but it was 8 before we sailed. It soon began to rain and we had a violent Gale of wind at Southeast, untill we reached New-Castle— The tide ran against us the whole way And was so high at New Castle that we found a difficulty to land at the wharf— It was two in the afternoon, before we left the Packet, which was the Diana, Captain Barnes— We immediately took the Stages, without stopping at Newcastle, and rode to the new place of embarkation on Elk-river, which is six miles below French-town, and is call’d Cecil-Point— The wind had come round to the North-west, just as we landed at Newcastle— The weather had cleared away; and in the Evening continued to blow a fresh gale— We barely stopp’d to sup at the point; and immediately embarked in the Packet President, Captain Ferguson. We sailed at about 8 in the Evening— This is a new line of Packets and Stages, which runs in competition with the old line, to Frenchtown; and they are extremely anxious to accomplish the passage, with the utmost possible dispatch— The distance travell’d by land, they call 24 miles—six miles further than to Frenchtown; but the water passage down Chesapeak Bay, is shortened in the same proportion— Of the members with whom I had travell’d to Philadelphia, only Mr: Ely and Coll: Hough continued with me, on this passage— Instead of the others, who left us there to pursue their route, by the different land Stages, we have now Mr: Gilman of New-Hampshire; Mr: Smith, Mr: Chittenden, Mr: Olin and Mr: Fiske all of Vermont— We have also two ladies—a Mrs: Jones of Philadelphia, with her Sister—and some other passengers.

27. About four O’Clock this morning we arrived at Baltimore, and waiting untill day-light, then proceeded to Evans’s tavern, where I breakfasted— I called afterwards upon Mr: N. Williams, and delivered to him Mr: Boylston’s papers— At 10 of the morning I left Baltimore in the Stage; with Mr: Gilman, Mr: Ely, Mr: Hough, and one other passenger
Our other companions from Philadelphia, had preceded us in the mail-Stage, at 8. this morning— We dined at Spurrier’s; fourteen miles from Baltimore; and I arrived, safely at Mr: Hellen’s in Washington, about eight O’Clock in the Evening— Having accomplished my Journey from Boston, in nine easy days travelling; without riding at Night. I found the family at Mr: Hellen’s all well— Mr: Sheldon was there.

28. This forenoon I paid a visit to the President, whom I found at home— Mr: D. R. Williams of S. Carolina, and Mr: Olin were with him— I had little conversation with him, and upon indifferent topics— I called also upon Mr: Madison, the Secretary of State, but he was not at home.— I spent the Evening at Mr: Boyd’s; but he was not at home.— Wrote to my wife.

29. I was confined to the house the whole day, by the weather which was a steady rain.— Dr: Weems was here in the morning. Mr: Boyd spent the Evening with us— I neither read nor wrote much in the course of this day; but I recommenced the perusal of Homer’s Odyssey in Greek, which has been suspended during my Journey— Began in the second Book where I left it, at Quincy, and Boston.

30. Heard Mr: Sayres, at the Church in Georgetown this morning; and Mr: Parrott at the Methodist Meeting in the afternoon. The Church has been finished; and the meeting house entirely new-built since I was here last Winter— Had a visit from Mr: Ducket, one of the Judges of the Circuit-Court for the District; appointed the last Winter— I called in the Evening with Catherine Johnson at his house; but he was not at home.— Finished reading the 2d: book of the Odyssey; and resumed the reading of the English Bible— I began also the perusal of Quinctilian, in the Abbé Gedoyn’s translation.— Spent the Evening in my chamber; but I do not yet find myself capable of useful application.

Day— During the first half of the month, it was like those which had preceded— The settlement of my family in Boston, and my own Journey to Washington employed eleven days, and since my arrival here, I have not yet got into any regular course of occupation.
